title: How to Paint a Watercolor of Seashells

steps.headline: Gather some actual shells if possible.
steps.description: Looking first hand at shells will give you a lot of information about how to proceed with your art piece. Probably the best thing is seeing shells will renew your excitement and curiosity about them.

steps.headline: Assemble your watercolor supplies.
steps.description: Heavy watercolor paper is the first item and is easily found at craft, art and discount stores in pad form. You will need an ordinary pencil with an eraser, a set of watercolors, a watercolor or all purpose brush, a water container and tissues to help control the drips.

steps.headline: Choose three different shaped seashells.
steps.description: Place them so they are clearly visible, in front of your paper and lightly sketch their outlines. (Tracing around them is fine for those who desire this help.) Keep your lines light and use your eraser to get the shells as you want them to appear in your painting.

steps.headline: Concentrate initially on painting just the three seashells.
steps.description: Background and other details can come later. For the first shell wet the shell shape first with clear water. Leave it alone for a few seconds to allow the water to soak into the paper slightly. As it begins to dry, the area will appear less shiny. Put a tiny amount of pure and hardly diluted pigment, any color, on the end of a pointed brush and touch it to the outside edge of the wet shell shape. The water ought to  carry the color over the entire wet shell shape. Drop in a second, even a third, barely diluted color if desired. Try not to help; trust the water and paint to do the job. Tip the paper to mix slightly if needed but be mindful of the pretty mingling colors and step back to let them set and dry.

steps.headline: Proceed to the next shell.
steps.description: This time, work on dry paper. Mix a little puddle of watercolor in the palette section of your paint set or on a white plastic lid or plate. Keep the color pale by carefully adding just a small amount of pigment to the puddle of water. Mix it thoroughly. Lightly paint it over the shell. Do it in as few strokes as possible and skip your brush so a few stripes of white paper are untouched. The white areas will add sparkle. Try not to go back into it and break the wash once it is down. You can add more soon, after this first layer dries.

steps.headline: Analyze the third shell.
steps.description: You decide how you want to do it. Repeat either of the two ways above or do a combination of both. Whatever you choose, try to do it quick, avoid stirring and disturbing the colors once applied. Allow all three of your shells to completely dry before continuing to work on them.

steps.headline: Do a second layer of color.
steps.description: Using your pencil, if desired, return to each shell and re-draw the markings you want the shell to have. Draw more details, too. Find out what to add by looking again at your actual shells. The fresh pencil lines will guide you and keep you on track. Some possibilities include: ridges, spikes, ribbing, twirls, spirals and any type of bumps, spots or other pattern you desire. Paint these details in watercolor, going carefully and waiting to paint over wet areas so as not to destroy the freshness of what you already put on the paper.

steps.headline: Remember this is an art piece, so you can be creative in your choice of textures, colors, patterns, lines and the like.
steps.description: If desired, include some signs of wear such as small holes or broken sections. Use a small pointed brush to add these details. Work slowly and carefully, staying away from wet areas. If you need to hasten the drying, use a hairdryer.

steps.headline: Add highlights and glamorous effects at the end.
Stop at this point if you are satisfied with your painting being solely about the pretty shells.
steps.description: If it page looks a little spare, draw and paint more shells. If you want to put them in a setting, think "beach." Surround them with sand, sandcastles, a sand pail and shovel, a glimpse of an irregular shoreline, blue water and sky. Or, try making a pattern with the shells, line them up in rows or make a circle of shells.

steps.headline: Keep this fresh and lovely shore painting and hang it for all to enjoy.
steps.description: A trip to the beach,regardless of the season, is yours to enjoy every time you look at this painting. Can't you almost smell the fresh, salty air, hear and see the gulls swooping overhead?

tyn: Seashells - if you don't have some you've found, stores of often carry them in the craft area.
Watercolor paper - #140 heavy weight paper in a pad
Watercolor paints - a set with primary and secondary colors or tubes, colors of your choice
Palette - a white, hard surface to mix colors
Brushes - a round #8,10 or 12, a round, fine tip brush and a soft wash brush
Water container - keep the water clean by changing it when it looks dirty
text:
Preparing Gather some actual shells if possible. Looking first hand at shells will give you a lot of information about how to proceed with your art piece. Probably the best thing is seeing shells will renew your excitement and curiosity about them. Assemble your watercolor supplies. Heavy watercolor paper is the first item and is easily found at craft, art and discount stores in pad form. You will need an ordinary pencil with an eraser, a set of watercolors, a watercolor or all purpose brush, a water container and tissues to help control the drips. Choose three different shaped seashells. Place them so they are clearly visible, in front of your paper and lightly sketch their outlines. (Tracing around them is fine for those who desire this help.) Keep your lines light and use your eraser to get the shells as you want them to appear in your painting. Painting Concentrate initially on painting just the three seashells. Background and other details can come later. For the first shell wet the shell shape first with clear water. Leave it alone for a few seconds to allow the water to soak into the paper slightly. As it begins to dry, the area will appear less shiny. Put a tiny amount of pure and hardly diluted pigment, any color, on the end of a pointed brush and touch it to the outside edge of the wet shell shape. The water ought to carry the color over the entire wet shell shape. Drop in a second, even a third, barely diluted color if desired. Try not to help; trust the water and paint to do the job. Tip the paper to mix slightly if needed but be mindful of the pretty mingling colors and step back to let them set and dry. Proceed to the next shell. This time, work on dry paper. Mix a little puddle of watercolor in the palette section of your paint set or on a white plastic lid or plate. Keep the color pale by carefully adding just a small amount of pigment to the puddle of water. Mix it thoroughly. Lightly paint it over the shell. Do it in as few strokes as possible and skip your brush so a few stripes of white paper are untouched. The white areas will add sparkle. Try not to go back into it and break the wash once it is down. You can add more soon, after this first layer dries. Analyze the third shell. You decide how you want to do it. Repeat either of the two ways above or do a combination of both. Whatever you choose, try to do it quick, avoid stirring and disturbing the colors once applied. Allow all three of your shells to completely dry before continuing to work on them. Do a second layer of color. Using your pencil, if desired, return to each shell and re-draw the markings you want the shell to have. Draw more details, too. Find out what to add by looking again at your actual shells. The fresh pencil lines will guide you and keep you on track. Some possibilities include: ridges, spikes, ribbing, twirls, spirals and any type of bumps, spots or other pattern you desire. Paint these details in watercolor, going carefully and waiting to paint over wet areas so as not to destroy the freshness of what you already put on the paper. Adding Details Remember this is an art piece, so you can be creative in your choice of textures, colors, patterns, lines and the like. If desired, include some signs of wear such as small holes or broken sections. Use a small pointed brush to add these details. Work slowly and carefully, staying away from wet areas. If you need to hasten the drying, use a hairdryer. Add highlights and glamorous effects at the end. If things have gotten too dark, use white-out or correction fluid from the dollar store for highlights. This opaque paint comes with its own little brush and if kept well sealed after use and it will last a long time. For iridescent effects, try brushing on dollar store iridescent nail polish or luminous eye shadow. Dust it on lightly with a Q-tip, a twist of tissue, or its own applicator. Metallic art markers are available as well as sets of iridescent watercolors. Paint in stick form is available at the craft store, too. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/43/Metallicwatrcolrs.jpg/459px-Metallicwatrcolrs.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/43/Metallicwatrcolrs.jpg/759px-Metallicwatrcolrs.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":351,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":580.4395604395604,"licensing":"

"} Stop at this point if you are satisfied with your painting being solely about the pretty shells. If it page looks a little spare, draw and paint more shells. If you want to put them in a setting, think "beach." Surround them with sand, sandcastles, a sand pail and shovel, a glimpse of an irregular shoreline, blue water and sky. Or, try making a pattern with the shells, line them up in rows or make a circle of shells. Keep this fresh and lovely shore painting and hang it for all to enjoy. A trip to the beach,regardless of the season, is yours to enjoy every time you look at this painting. Can't you almost smell the fresh, salty air, hear and see the gulls swooping overhead?
sentences: Preparing Gather some actual shells if possible.
Looking first hand at shells will give you a lot of information about how to proceed with your art piece.
Probably the best thing is seeing shells will renew your excitement and curiosity about them.
Assemble your watercolor supplies.
Heavy watercolor paper is the first item and is easily found at craft, art and discount stores in pad form.
You will need an ordinary pencil with an eraser, a set of watercolors, a watercolor or all purpose brush, a water container and tissues to help control the drips.
Choose three different shaped seashells.
Place them so they are clearly visible, in front of your paper and lightly sketch their outlines.
(Tracing around them is fine for those who desire this help.)
Keep your lines light and use your eraser to get the shells as you want them to appear in your painting.
Painting Concentrate initially on painting just the three seashells.
Background and other details can come later.
For the first shell wet the shell shape first with clear water.
Leave it alone for a few seconds to allow the water to soak into the paper slightly.
As it begins to dry, the area will appear less shiny.
Put a tiny amount of pure and hardly diluted pigment, any color, on the end of a pointed brush and touch it to the outside edge of the wet shell shape.
The water ought to  carry the color over the entire wet shell shape.
Drop in a second, even a third, barely diluted color if desired.
Try not to help; trust the water and paint to do the job.
Tip the paper to mix slightly if needed but be mindful of the pretty mingling colors and step back to let them set and dry.
Proceed to the next shell.
This time, work on dry paper.
Mix a little puddle of watercolor in the palette section of your paint set or on a white plastic lid or plate.
Keep the color pale by carefully adding just a small amount of pigment to the puddle of water.
Mix it thoroughly.
Lightly paint it over the shell.
Do it in as few strokes as possible and skip your brush so a few stripes of white paper are untouched.
The white areas will add sparkle.
Try not to go back into it and break the wash once it is down.
You can add more soon, after this first layer dries.
Analyze the third shell.
You decide how you want to do it.
Repeat either of the two ways above or do a combination of both.
Whatever you choose, try to do it quick, avoid stirring and disturbing the colors once applied.
Allow all three of your shells to completely dry before continuing to work on them.
Do a second layer of color.
Using your pencil, if desired, return to each shell and re-draw the markings you want the shell to have.
Draw more details, too.
Find out what to add by looking again at your actual shells.
The fresh pencil lines will guide you and keep you on track.
Some possibilities include: ridges, spikes, ribbing, twirls, spirals and any type of bumps, spots or other pattern you desire.
Paint these details in watercolor, going carefully and waiting to paint over wet areas so as not to destroy the freshness of what you already put on the paper.
Adding Details Remember this is an art piece, so you can be creative in your choice of textures, colors, patterns, lines and the like.
If desired, include some signs of wear such as small holes or broken sections.
Use a small pointed brush to add these details.
Work slowly and carefully, staying away from wet areas.
If you need to hasten the drying, use a hairdryer.
Add highlights and glamorous effects at the end.
If things have gotten too dark, use white-out or correction fluid from the dollar store for highlights.
This opaque paint comes with its own little brush and if kept well sealed after use and it will last a long time.
For iridescent effects, try brushing on dollar store iridescent nail polish or luminous eye shadow.
Dust it on lightly with a Q-tip, a twist of tissue, or its own applicator.
Metallic art markers are available as well as sets of iridescent watercolors.
Paint in stick form is available at the craft store, too.

"} Stop at this point if you are satisfied with your painting being solely about the pretty shells.
If it page looks a little spare, draw and paint more shells.
If you want to put them in a setting, think "beach."
Surround them with sand, sandcastles, a sand pail and shovel, a glimpse of an irregular shoreline, blue water and sky.
Or, try making a pattern with the shells, line them up in rows or make a circle of shells.
Keep this fresh and lovely shore painting and hang it for all to enjoy.
A trip to the beach,regardless of the season, is yours to enjoy every time you look at this painting.
Can't you almost smell the fresh, salty air, hear and see the gulls swooping overhead?
